diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug Reactions (including Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms [DRESS] Syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Viral infections (e.g., dengue fever, Zika virus)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Reactive lymphadenopathy due to viral or bacterial infection
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)

Central nervous system infection (e.g., meningitis, encephalitis)
Rickettsial diseases (Typhus, Rocky Mountain spotted fever)
Epilepsy (in the context of a new-onset seizure)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, if unrelated to other systemic findings)
Schizophrenia (considering psychosis as a primary symptom, unrelated to other conditions)
Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) associated with another condition

diagnoses.description: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.rationale: Hyperglycemia is a hallmark sign of diabetes mellitus. This condition can also affect blood circulation and nerve function, potentially leading to anemia and dysgeusia.

diagnoses.description: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.rationale: Iron deficiency anemia is directly indicated by anemia. It can also lead to dysgeusia or an altered sense of taste due to iron's role in taste receptor function.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Can result in anemia due to reduced erythropoietin production, dysgeusia from toxin build-up, and hyperglycemia if diabetes is a causative factor. Angioedema can occur as a response to certain treatments.

diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause hyperglycemia through its effect on slowing metabolism. Anemia and dysgeusia are also common. Angioedema might occur, though less frequently.

diagnoses.description: Zinc Deficiency
diagnoses.rationale: Can lead to dysgeusia and anemia. It can indirectly impact glucose metabolism, potentially affecting hyperglycemia.

diagnoses.description: Autoimmune Disorders (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause anemia and dysgeusia. Some autoimmune disorders might lead to hyperglycemia due to inflammation or steroid treatment and angioedema as an allergic response.

diagnoses.description: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause anemia from malabsorption of nutrients such as iron and B12, dysgeusia due to deficiencies, and potentially contribute to hyperglycemia through mechanisms affecting insulin sensitivity.

diagnoses.description: Liver Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Can present with anemia due to various factors such as malabsorption, dysgeusia from accumulation of certain metabolites, and angioedema as a result of altered proteins.

diagnoses.description: Nutritional Deficiencies
diagnoses.rationale: Deficiencies in B12, folate, iron, and zinc can directly cause anemia and dysgeusia. Poor nutrition can contribute to an increased risk of hyperglycemia.

diagnoses.description: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily characterized by recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema), it may incidentally correlate with anemia and dysgeusia as part of a complex clinical picture. Hyperglycemia as a direct symptom is less typical but could relate to treatment complications or secondary health issues.

diagnoses: Connective Tissue Disorders (e.g., Lupus, Rheumatoid Arthritis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, various skin conditions, and possibly laryngitis due to involvement of the larynx.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that make tears and saliva. It can lead to dry mouth and eyes, and potentially affect other organs and systems. Lymphadenopathy is also a common feature.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. Symptoms can include mouth sores, genital sores (leading to vaginitis), skin problems, and more.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) damages the immune system and can lead to Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS). Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, various infections, and a wide range of systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it's known for symptoms like fever, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A tick-borne illness that can cause a wide range of symptoms, depending on the stage of the disease. Early symptoms may include rash, fever, headache, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Chlamydia/Gonorrhea
diagnoses.description: Sexually transmitted infections that can present with vaginitis, pelvic pain, and potentially lead to further systemic symptoms if left untreated.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs but can spread to lymph nodes and other organs, presenting with lymphadenopathy among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs but most commonly affects the lungs and lymph nodes, leading to lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can worsen with physical or mental activity, but doesn't improve with rest. It can be associated with a host of symptoms including postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS) and decreased libido.

diagnoses: Preeclampsia/eclampsia (in the context of miscarriage and hypertension)
Antiphospholipid syndrome (in the context of miscarriage)
Electrolyte Imbalance (including Magnesium and Potassium deficiencies)

diagnoses.description: Chronic inflammatory diseases
diagnoses.detail: Conditions like autoimmune disorders can manifest with a combination of these symptoms.

diagnoses.description: Endocrine disorders
diagnoses.detail: Especially thyroid diseases can cause attention deficits, sleep disturbances, and altered temperature regulation.

diagnoses.description: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.detail: Characterized by widespread pain, sleep problems, fatigue, and often attention deficits.

diagnoses.description: Sleep disorders
diagnoses.detail: Conditions such as sleep apnea might contribute to non-restorative sleep and attention issues.

diagnoses.description: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.detail: May lead to or exacerbate sleep problems and attention deficits, potentially affecting immune function.

diagnoses.description: Depression
diagnoses.detail: Can manifest with sleep disturbance, immune system problems, and attention deficits.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.detail: Characterized by severe fatigue, sleep abnormalities, and sometimes attention problems.

diagnoses.description: Immunodeficiency disorders
diagnoses.detail: Primary or secondary conditions that result in an increased susceptibility to infection.

diagnoses.description: Adrenal disorders
diagnoses.detail: Conditions like Addison's disease can affect temperature regulation, immune system function, and psychological health.

diagnoses.description: Rheumatologic conditions
diagnoses.detail: Diseases such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis that might present with a range of symptoms including those listed.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Substance Use Disorders (e.g., Alcohol Withdrawal leading to hyperthermia)

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur suddenly after exposure to an allergen. Symptoms include hypotension, angioedema, and gastrointestinal symptoms like abdominal cramps and diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Food Poisoning
diagnoses.description: Illness caused by consuming contaminated food. Common symptoms include abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and in some cases, hypotension due to dehydration.

diagnoses.name: Acute Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the stomach and intestines typically caused by a viral or bacterial infection. Symptomatic presentation may include diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and dehydration leading to hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain types of bacterial infections. Symptoms can include hypotension, rash, and gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder that results in recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema). It occasionally causes abdominal cramping due to swelling of the intestinal wall and can lead to hypotension if the upper airway is affected.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Gastroenteropathy
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction affecting the gastrointestinal tract. Symptoms can include abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and in some cases, hypotension and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Septic Shock
diagnoses.description: A significant drop in blood pressure that can occur with severe infection (sepsis), leading to hypotension. Symptoms may also include gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder that occurs when the adrenal glands do not produce enough of their hormones. Symptoms can include hypotension, abdominal cramps, and in some cases, nausea and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause a variety of symptoms depending on which organs are affected. It can lead to hypotension, abdominal pain, and in some cases, skin changes or angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Insect Sting Allergy
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction to the venom of stinging insects. While not typically associated with abdominal cramps or diarrhea, severe reactions can cause angioedema, hypotension, and in some cases, conjunctival injections.

diagnoses: Environmental allergies (pollen, dust mites, molds, animal dander)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden weakness, difficulty speaking, and loss of vision or scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraine with aura is a type of migraine that involves visual disturbances (scotoma or flashing lights), which is usually followed by a severe headache. Migraine attacks can also include aphasia, weakness, and less commonly, vertigo and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a chronic illness involving your central nervous system (CNS). The immune system attacks myelin, which is the protective layer around nerve fibers, causing inflammation and scar tissue. This can lead to a wide range of symptoms including weakness, difficulty speaking (aphasia), vision problems (scotoma), and less frequently, vertigo and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor involves abnormal cell growth within the brain. Depending on the location and type of the tumor, symptoms can vary widely but may include weakness, scotoma, aphasia, vertigo, and vomiting due to increased intracranial pressure.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: A transient ischemic attack (TIA), often referred to as a 'mini-stroke', is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. It can include weakness, difficulty with speech (aphasia), scotoma, vertigo, and less commonly, vomiting. TIAs typically last few minutes to hours and should be treated urgently as they can precede a full stroke.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Vestibular neuritis is inflammation of the vestibular nerve, a nerve in the ear that helps control balance. This can lead to vertigo, vomiting, and, in some cases, symptoms like visual disturbances (scotoma) due to the disorientation.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck, but can also lead to weakness, aphasia, and in severe cases, vomiting and consciousness disturbances including scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain. The cause is often viral, but it can also result from bacterial infections and other causes. Symptoms can include headache, fever, confusion, seizures, and in more severe cases, weakness, aphasia, scotoma, vertigo, and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: An acoustic neuroma is a benign tumor on the vestibulocochlear nerve, which connects the inner ear with the brain. This tumor can cause vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus, and in some cases, symptoms like weakness (due to compression of nearby structures), scotoma (as part of increased intracranial pressure), and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Among its varied symptoms, significant episodes can lead to postictal weakness, aphasia, and less commonly, vomiting. Vision disturbances like scotoma could occur during or after seizures in certain types of epilepsy.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition in which poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms may include inability to move or feel on one side of the body, problems understanding or speaking, dizziness, or loss of vision to one side.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare neurological disorder in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks part of its peripheral nervous system—the network of nerves located outside of the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can include weakness, numbness, and tingling.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from not enough vitamin B12. Symptoms may include fatigue, weakness, constipation, loss of appetite, weight loss, poor memory, and numbness and tingling in the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms can vary but may include headaches, seizures, problem with vision, vomiting, and mental changes.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes. Symptoms include high blood sugar levels, numbness, tingling, or weakness in the feet and hands.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It’s frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingleness, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms include headache, fever, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A result of damage to the nerves outside of the brain and spinal cord (peripheral nerves), often causes weakness, numbness and pain, usually in your hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief period of symptoms similar to those you'd have in a stroke. Symptoms may include weakness, numbness or paralysis in your face, arm or leg, typically on one side of your body.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms may include headache, aphasia (difficulty speaking or understanding speech), and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke, but usually lasting only a few minutes and causing no permanent damage. Common symptoms include weakness, headache, aphasia, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines are a type of headache characterized by intense pain. 'With aura' refers to migraines that are preceded or accompanied by sensory disturbances called 'aura,' including scintillating scotomas (flashing, shimmering lights), speech disturbances, and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor involves the growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Symptoms depend on the tumor's size, location, and rate of growth but often include headaches, weakness, aphasia, and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck, but might also include aphasia and weakness if areas of the brain are affected.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis is a disease of the central nervous system that disrupts the flow of information within the brain, and between the brain and body. Symptoms vary widely and can include fatigue, difficulty walking (weakness), numbness or weakness in one or more limbs, and speech disturbances (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, including visual disturbances like scintillation, and sometimes loss of awareness or aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain, often caused by an infection. Symptoms can be mild, such as headache and weakness, or more severe, such as aphasia, seizures, and hallucinations.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: This is bleeding into the subarachnoid space — the area between the brain and the tissues that cover it. Symptoms include a sudden, severe headache, often followed by nausea, vomiting, photophobia (light sensitivity), and sometimes aphasia or weakness if the brain is affected.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: Temporal arteritis is an inflammation of the blood vessels, called arteries, in and around the scalp. Symptoms may include a severe headache, scalp tenderness, jaw pain, vision problems, weakness, and sometimes symptoms affecting speech (aphasia).

diagnoses: Vasculitis, such as Microscopic Polyangiitis or Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Vitamin B12 Deficiency or Folate Deficiency
